datafield.subfield: Carta ejecutoria de Hidalguia granted in favor of Diego de Alarcón Quintana de la Villa de la Torre and his sons, unnamed :

The opening formula (Don Phelipe / por la gracia de dios / rey de Castilla / de Leon de Aragon de las) is incorporated into four full-page miniatures: the first depicting a male figure and his two sons kneeling in prayer beneath the crucified Christ, four saints in the frame (fol. 1v); the second depicting his wife with four daughters kneeling in prayer before the Virgin Mary, who is surrounded by symbols of her attributes (hortus, fons, speculum, civitas, etc.), four saints in the frame (fol. 2r); the third shows St. George in battle against the Saracens (fol. 2v); the fourth is presumably the full coat of arms of the grantee, Don Diego (fol. 3v); several 9- to 10-line decorated initials throughout, the final one historiated with a male figure holding a sceptre (fol. 139r); each leaf is ruled in slate blue and surrounded by a 4 mm. frame of gold and dark brown; three red silk covering leaves sewn-in to protect the miniatures.
Unrestricted in reading room, but coach user: tight binding, open only to 90°, use book supports; available for classroom use in exhibit case only.

The first document mentioned was given in 1598, and the final section, written by the notary Salvador Rico (fol. 140v) is dated 1609. A note (fol. 1r) may give prices for the production of the manuscript, including the seda y plomo.

MS 3327, Container 111: Edward A. Parsons (1878-1962) of New Orleans, Louisiana; bookplate on the inside front cover but not listed in De Ricci; a note in pencil on the back pastedown indicates it was purchased in Granada on 4 August 1926. Binding: faded blue velvet over wood boards; velvet is probably mid-20th century. A white, green, yellow, blue, and red silk cord of authentication is incorporated into the binding, but the lead seal is lacking.
